data.author: Abrar Rahman Protyasha
data.message:
Remove use of leading underscore for submodules (#6)

The leading underscore naming convention is used for "private" symbols
in Python, and as such, was being used inappropriately (and excessively)
in this package. This commit addresses that concern and only keeps true
implementation details private.

A sid-effect of this PR is that automated document generation tools such
as `sphinx-apidoc` can generate more detailed documentation for the
package.

Signed-off-by: Abrar Rahman Protyasha <abrar@openrobotics.org>

Change default enclave paths from `"/"` to `"/<node_name>"` (#4)

data.author: Abrar Rahman Protyasha
data.message:
Removing optional output filename from `convert` verb usage (#11)

* Removing optional output filename with a default

This change achieves the following:

* Simplifies the `convert` verb usage.
* Gets rid of some tricky policy XML file handling business.
* Ensures safer behavior of the `convert` verb, in that an
existing file is not overwritten in any circumstance (unless
the user specifically redirects to that effect).

Signed-off-by: Abrar Rahman Protyasha <abrar@openrobotics.org>

* Changed `convert` verb tests to reflect new usage

The unit tests do not reflect an output policy XML file anymore,
which simplifies both the testing logic (no use of `tmp_path_factory`
anymore) and the number of tests required.

Signed-off-by: Abrar Rahman Protyasha <abrar@openrobotics.org>

* Fixing alphabetic ordering in package listings

Signed-off-by: Abrar Rahman Protyasha <abrar@openrobotics.org>

* Explicitly use of context manager in `get_profile`

This commit avoids a layer of indirection in having to
call the `_get_profile_path`, which opens a context manager
only to return a file path immediately.
Instead, `_get_profile_path` is removed completely and
the `with` statement is open-coded into the `get_profile`
function, which is the only place that context manager
is required.

Signed-off-by: Abrar Rahman Protyasha <abrar@openrobotics.org>

* Removing memoization pattern from _common._profile

The global Python objects for the common permissions was
an attempt at memoization, but with an unusual pattern.
Given there was no reason to actually try to optimize, and
since the `common_[role]_[permission]` functions will be
called very infrequently, that design pattern can be
eliminated entirely, calling `_get_items_by_role` as required.

NB: this design pattern might require further modification
in the future if lifecycle nodes are ever formalized as a
concept into this tool.

Signed-off-by: Abrar Rahman Protyasha <abrar@openrobotics.org>

* Remove unnecessary 'Optional' type hint

Signed-off-by: Abrar Rahman Protyasha <abrar@openrobotics.org>

data.author: Abrar Rahman Protyasha
data.message:
"Complete"-ed NoDL conversion API

Concerns:
* Enclave paths are not well specified. Is it fair to make an
assumption and default to `"[node_name][executable_name]"`?
* Node namespaces are also not well specified. It certainly is
not fair to assume all nodes belong to the unspecified `"/"`
general namespace.

Both of the above concerns can be addressed by expanding the
definition of the node interface description language. This
discussion probably has a place in ros2/design#266.

TO-DO:
* Verify whether default enclave paths should be left blank
or should be set to an unqualified general path ("/")
* Writing unit and functional tests for the `nodl_to_policy`
utility.

Signed-off-by: Abrar Rahman Protyasha <abrar@openrobotics.org>

data.author: Abrar Rahman Protyasha
data.message:
Partially defining the policy conversion API

In this commit:
* Sketched some ideas, in comments, about the conversion process.
* Defined a simple `write_policy` that relies on the XSLT operation
performed in `sros2.policy.dump_policy` for successful policy XML
file generation.

Confusions:
* What to do about the enclave paths? I'm not sure if there's a
simple, non-intuitive way to extract node process paths from the NoDL
description.
* Does the `xpointer` and `xinclude` shenanigans in the example ROS 2
access control policy files get placed through the transpiling in
`sros2.policy.dump_policy`? If not, where do they come into play?

Signed-off-by: Abrar Rahman Protyasha <abrar@openrobotics.org>

calls to policy conversion/write functions, as will be defined shortly.
